channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Future is Now! Perl Role in Malaysia
item.description: Our client is an online financial services company, still rapidly expanding after 20 years of impressive growth. With a truly international presence, they’re well known globally in their niche. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: A Role that Makes Dollars (and Cents). Perl Developer Role in London
item.description: If you are a senior Perl/JS programmer with a passion for finance and business, this could be the role you’ve been waiting for. Our client is looking for an individual who understands Go programming languages, is experienced with Python and Django, and knows the ins and outs of databases like MySQL, and NoSQL databases like Google BigTable.

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Our client takes the legwork out of the hunt for the best bargain, offering one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re looking for a heroic Perl programmer to develop and deliver quality content and all the info users need to find their gadgets for the right price.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. They’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems. Strong Modern Perl is a must and Python is a Bonus.

item.title: Live Crystal Shardbox development with Johannes Müller (straight-shoota)
Testing 3rd party packages on end-user's machine during installation
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Live Video - Binary Palindrome by Mohammad Anwar
Live Video - Missing Row by Mohammad Anwar
Weekly Challenge 118
item.description: Simon also split the task #2 into smaller task to make it easier to explain. I loved it. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 118: Binary Knight
item.description: Roger took a very different route to solve task #1. I liked it. Roger attempt of breaking down task #2 is much appreciated. It made the solution easy to follow. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 118
item.description: Interesting use of PDL to solve the task #2 of the week. Thank you for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 118: Binary Palindrome
item.description: I really admire the dedication of Laurent as he managed to find time to solve the task. Well done.

item.title: TDD a perlscript with modulinos (PWC-118)
item.description: A great example of how to follow TDD in solving weekly task. Welcome back BTW.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #118
item.description: James has nailed the task #2 with plenty of different solutions. Take your sweet time to go each one of them.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 118
item.description: Do you want to learn Iterative Deepening A* or IDA*? Well this will definitely help you. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Knight thginK: Perl Weekly Challenge #118
item.description: Dave spent good amount of time to go into the details of his solution to the second task. It shows the dedication. Keep up the great work.

item.title: PWC118 - Adventure of Knight
item.description: Usually Flavio keeps his blog short and sweet but for this task he went on full fledged to share the behind the scene story.

item.title: PWC118 - Binary Palindrome
item.description: Bitwise operation is rare these day. Thank you Flavio for reminding us.

item.title: A Knight’s Quest: A Search for His Pal
item.description: The highlight of the blog, to me personally, is the cute little regex for Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: CY's Puzzle Created for The Weekly Challenge #118 ‐ Pre-processing
item.description: Cheok-Yin being the creator of the task #2, she took special interest in explaining every little things about the task. I appreciate her sincerity.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #118 Task 1
item.description: You should definitely check out her interpretation of the task #1. I enjoyed it thoroughly.

item.title: Binary Knight with Raku (and Perl)
item.description: Thank you Arne for taking part in the weekly challenge even while on holiday. I loved the story behind the second task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 118: Adventure of Knight
item.description: Abigail shared very unique aspects of the task #2, at least for me. I wasn't aware of such thing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 118: Binary Palindrome
item.description: Abigail being the master of regex, he came up with one-liner regex to solve the task. Incredible.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 118
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Binary Palindrome" and "Adventure of Knight" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 119
item.description: Welcome a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Swap Nibbles" and "Sequence without 1-on-1". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: The Perl echo chamber, marketing and … is Perl really dying?
item.description: Interesting points being raised/discussed in the blog. Please do checkout.

item.title: What they say in Java is just as true in Perl
item.description: Interesting post, you don't want to miss out.

item.title: Whither Perl: Blue Collar Blues
item.description: Do you agree with him?

item.title: Perl can escape the Lisp Curse
item.description: Another interesting blog by Mark. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Internals University
item.description: Do you want to learn XS/C and Perl internals? You can now by backing the Kickstarter project.

item.title: The story of eBooks and me
item.description: Interesting story behind the creation of Clapham Technical Press.

item.title: Perl Steering Council Term Election 2021 Completed
item.description: David shared the news that Paul Evans joined the team officially. Congratulations Paul.

item.title: #518 - Becoming book author?
item.description:
Hi there

I recently came across a blog post by Dave Cross where he shared his story how he got into publishing ebook. I highly recommend you read his blog, I find it inspirational, personally. I always wanted to write technical book on the subject related to Perl. I have high regards for those who are professional authors e.g. Curtis Poe, brian d foy, Gabor Szabo, Dave Cross and many more. Ever since I started the weekly challenge, I became more involved in writing technical blog. Soon I realised it is not the same as writing a technical book. But the urge inside me to become an author didn't die forever. With recent Dave's blog kind of fan the idea once again. I became charged one more time but this time I am seriously thinking about it. I had a topic that I wanted to explore for sometimes. I discussed it with Gabor and Dave and got very positive response. So it is official I am now working on my first book, soon to be published by Dave Cross. Fingers Crossed. Life is so beautiful when you have friends like Gabor and Dave who always encourage and guide you.

There is another story that I would like to share about. Andrew Shitov reached out to me few days ago if I am interested to share my Raku story in the upcoming The Raku Conference. I have accepted the offer and working on it. I haven't submitted my talk yet but will do so soon. Do you have Raku story to share? If yes then please do submit your talk before the deadline.

One last story of the week and I would go away. Many of you know that I have been running the Perl Weekly Challenge for more than 2 years now. It started as a weekly challenge aimed for Perl and Raku community but soon it spread out to other languages. As of today, we now have received contributions in over 50 different languages. Latest addition is Crystal programming language by none other than the Gabor Szabo himself. Long time ago, don't remember who, proposed to me to register a generic domain instead of perlweeklychallenge.org. I didn't waste the time and registered the new domain theweeklychallenge.org. Having registered the new domain, I didn't have the courage and expertise to switch over the actively used live site to another domain. I made a request in this regard on Facebook and guess what? Dave Cross came up with step-by-step guide to do the domain switch. I was still very nervous to take the risk. Then came the final blow with Gabor asking the same question why don't I move domain to a generic domain. To cut the long story short, Gabor and I spent an hour or so yesterday, (Sunday afternoon), got the domain switch over. So we now have new domain the weekly challenge: theweeklychallenge.org. Thank you Gabor and Dave for all the support and guidance.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter
